abstract.p: Brazilian government, in move intended to promote economic growth, sets inflation target of 3.5 percent for 2002, down only slightly from 4 percent target for next year; inflation is expected to be 6 percent this year; government also lowers long-term interest rate to 10.25 percent from 11 percent; photo of Pres Henrique Cardoso; photo (S)

block.p: In a move intended to promote economic growth, the Brazilian government set an inflation target of 3.5 percent for 2002, down only slightly from the 4 percent target for next year. Brazilian monetary policy, based on inflation targets, anticipates inflation of 6 percent this year. The 2002 inflation target had been awaited as an indication of how fiscally austere President Henrique Cardoso, above, intended to be in 2002, the last year of his term. The government also lowered a long-term interest rate to 10.25 percent from 11 percent.
